list-item.p: Hormel Foundation 4th Annual Gifted and Talented Education Symposium at the Riverland Community College in Austin, MN. For more information, please visit https://www.austin.k12.mn.us/educationalservices/GTsymposium/default.aspx
Kentucky Association for Gifted Education (KAGE) Summer Workshop at Western Kentucky University in Bowling Green, KY. For more information, please visit http://kagegifted.org/
Global Virtual Meeting for Gifted Education in Second Life. For more information, please visit http://www.begabungszentrum-bayern.de/global-virtual-meeting-for-gifted-education-in-secondlife/
PG Retreat for families with highly and profoundly gifted children at the Glyn Eyrie Castle in Colorado Springs, CO. For more information, please visit http://pgretreat.com/
Mensa International Annual Gathering in Reno, NV. For more information, please visit http://www.ag2012.us.mensa.org//AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home14
The 35th Annual Confratute Summer Institute at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, CT. For more information, please visit http://www.gifted.uconn.edu/confratute/
The International Centre for Innovation in Education (ICIE) Conference on Excellence in Education in Jerusalem. For more information, please visit http://www.jerusalem.icieconference.net/

The Professional Summer Institute on Curriculum and Instruction for High Ability Learners in Diverse Settings at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, VA. For more information, please visit http://education.wm.edu/centers/cfge/

Weeks 1 and 2 of the 2011 Summer Institute on Academic Diversity at The University of Virginia Curry School of Education in Charlottesville, VA. For more information, please visit http://curry.virginia.edu/research/projects/summer-institute-on-academic-diversity
Equity Gifted Education 13th National Conference in Adelaide, South Australia. For more information, please visit http://gtcasa.asn.au/wp/
SENG (Supporting Emotional Needs of the Gifted) Summit in Milwaukee, WI. For more information, please visit http://www.sengifted.org/programs/conferences/milwaukee-2012-conference
Asia-Pacific Conference on Giftedness 2012 at the Dubai International Convention & Exhibition Center in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. For more information, please visit http://www.giftedness2012.com/
9th Annual Institute for Teachers of Gifted Youth University of South Dakota at the University of South Dakota in Vermillion, SD. For more information, please visit http://sd-agc.org/
10th International Dabrowski Congress at the Curtis Doubletree Hotel in Denver, CO. For more information, please visit http://www.gifteddevelopment.com/Dabrowski/index.html
California Homeschooling Network Family Expo at the Radisson Ontario Airport in Ontario, CA. For more information, please visit http://chnfamilyexpo.com/
The 16th Annual Edufest at Boise State University in Boise, ID. For more information, please visit http://www.edufest.org/
32nd Annual International Conference on Critical Thinking at the Claremont Resort Hotel & Spa in Berkeley, CA. For more information, please visit http://www.criticalthinking.org/conference/index.cfm
The Professional Summer Institute on Curriculum and Instruction for High Ability Learners in Diverse Settings in Richmond, VA. For more information, please visit http://education.wm.edu/centers/cfge/
BrickFair 2012 LEGO Fan Festival and Convention at the Dulles Expo Center in Chantilly, VA. For more information, please visit http://www.brickfair.com/
Northeast Unschooling Conference at the Sheraton Colonial Hotel in Wakefield, MA. For more information, please visit http://www.northeastunschoolingconference.com/
The Association for the Gifted fall conference at Waco, Texas. For more information, please visit http://www.baylor.edu/soe/index.php?id=65437
13th International ECHA Conference at the University of Münster in Münster, Germany. For more information, please visit http://www.echa2012.info/conference
South Dakota Association for Gifted Children Fall Conference (SD-AGC) at the Best Western Ramkota Inn in Pierre, SD. For more information, please visit http://www.sd-agc.org/
Alabama Association for Gifted Children (AAGC) Conference at the McWane Science Center in Birmingham, AL. For more information, please visit http://www.alabamagifted.org/
Forum 2012 sponsored by the College Board at the Fontainebleau Miami Beach in Miami Beach, FL For more information, visit http://forum.collegeboard.org/

National Association for Gifted Children annual conference, “Reaching Beyond the Summit: Educating With Altitude,” at Denver Convention Center in Denver, CO. For more information, visit http://www.nagc.org/
Texas Association for the Gifted and Talented annual conference, “Building Connections,” at the Sheraton Dallas in Dallas, TX. For more information, visit http://www.txgifted.org/

boxed-text.title: Did you know that …
boxed-text.p: … 903,630 U.S. public high school graduates took at least one AP exam.
… 616,412 U.S. public high school graduates reported AP scores to college and universities.
… 128,568 U.S. high school teachers taught an AP course.
… 5,808 college faculty participated in reviewing AP teachers’ syllabi, developing curricula, or scoring AP exams.
… 3,293 U.S. colleges and universities received AP scores for credit, placement, and/or consideration in the admission process.
… 202,725 U.S. public high school graduates took AP Calculus AB.
… 14,537 U.S. high school teachers taught AP calculus AB in 2010-2011.
… 540,619 U.S. public high school graduates scored 3+ on an AP exam.
… 18.1% of U.S. public high school graduates took AP courses and scored a 3 or higher.
… 313,452 U.S. public high school graduates took at least one AP science exam.
… 154,536 scored 3+ on an AP science exam at any point in high school.
… 330,296 U.S. public high school graduates took at least one AP math exam.
… 187,844 scored 3+ on an AP math exam at any point in high school.
… 19 states exceeded the national average of graduates scoring a 3 or higher.
… 57.1% of a possible 59.2% of the school population taking AP exams were White.
… 17.0% of a possible 17.6% of the school population taking AP exams were Hispanic.
… 9.0% of a possible 14.7% of the school population taking AP exams were Black.
… 10.3% of a possible .75% of the school population taking AP exams were Asian.
… 0.6% of a possible 1.1% of the school population taking AP exams were American Indian.
… 59.4% of AP exam takers were from low-income minority groups.
… 5.9% of Hispanic AP exam takers took AP Spanish Language before taking other AP exams.
… 79.7% of eligible Blacks did not participate in a recommended AP subject.
… 73.7% of eligible American Indians did not participate in a recommended AP subject.
… 70.4% of eligible Hispanics did not participate in a recommended AP subject.
… 61.6% of eligible Whites did not participate in a recommended AP subject.
… 42.1% of eligible Asians did not participate in a recommended AP subject.
Statistics from the College Board’s 8th Annual AP Report to the Nation. (2012, February). Retrieved from http://apreport.collegeboard.org
